results.title: Lease on life
results.creator_credit: Ermerson Yorke Studio and Emerson Yorke
results.brief_description: The story of an average American family and how they plan to avoid unnecessary illness. Shows the forces of prevention in action, the conflict between superstition and fact, and the effective combination of skilled hands and trained minds in medical teamwork, with special reference to anti-tuberculosis measures.

results.title: Learning: a happy experience (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: FilmFair Communications and Carolyn Sue Benson
results.brief_description: Highlights the value of a happy and stimulating classroom atmosphere. Participation, individuality, flexibility and personal investigation by the children, help to develop positive attitudes towards school and learning.

results.title: Learning Walmajarri (PC & MAC) (A)
results.creator_credit: Catholic Education Office of Western Australia
results.brief_description: SYSTEM REQUIREMENTS: PC; Multimedia capable Pentium running Windows 95.16 megabytes RAM, (32 megabytes RAM recommended). Monitor 640 x 480 resolution, 16 bit colour (thousands of colours), 8X CD drive or faster. External speakers or headphones. MAC; 68040 (30Mhz) or better (Power PC recommended) running Mac 0S 7.5 or later. Minimum of 8 megabytes FREE application RAM. DO NOT USE VIRTUAL MEMORY. Monitor 640 x 480 resolution, 16 bit colour (thousands of colours). 8X CD drive or faster. Optional external speakers or headphones. Jointly funded by the Catholic Education Office in the Kimberley region and two schools - Kururrungku Catholic Education Centre and John Pujajangka Plyrin Catholic School, ‘Learning Walmajarri’ is the result of digitising elements of the program taught by tribal elders in the Walmajarri-speaking areas around Broome. “The multimedia format of a CD is well suited to the oral tradition, which is the context in which the elders teach their language, using songs and stories to impart vocabulary and syntax”(‘The Australian’ Tuesday June 8 199 pg. 20). Designed to assist in improving literacy amongst Walmajarri speakers, this program uses jigsaws and traditional stories and songs as entertaining instruction, although people who have no previous experience with Walmajarri may be tempted to give it a try.

results.title: Learning together: the handicapped person in the community
results.brief_description: Looks at two children, one with cerebral palsy and the other almost totally blind, at a nursery school which takes a small number of handicapped children alongside its non-handicapped. We see them engaged in various activities as the headmistress talks about the implications and advantages of having them in the school.

results.title: Learning to use your senses
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and Arthur R. Botham
results.brief_description: Explains the functions of the five senses - sight, hearing, touch, smell and taste - and shows how to recognise situations relevant to each of the five senses in the context of a birthday party.

results.title: Learning to swim: the back crawl
results.brief_description: After a demonstration of the back crawl by an expert, a class of children is seen practising the movements which make up the stroke until they can perform it themselves. Finally the expert is seen again in slow motion, and the finer points of the stroke is described in detail.

results.title: Learning to swim with artifical aids
results.brief_description: A teacher shows children what they can do with swimming aids. Elementary versions of breast, front and back crawl strokes are introduced. The flipper-float method is also shown on both the back and the front.

results.title: Learning to read maps. - 2nd ed.
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films, Acorn Films and David Jay
results.brief_description: A mimed fantasy about a lost clown who helps children understand the usefulness of maps. Teaches students that maps are graphic representations of real places, how to recognize symbols representing physical features on maps, how to find directions without using a compass and how to calculate distances to a destination.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films, Acorn Films and David Jay
